intro: Acalypha schinzii, commonly known as the red-leaf acalypha, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa. It is characterized by its striking, velvety red leaves that contrast with its green stems. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically green or yellowish in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and prefers partial to full sunlight. Acalypha schinzii is often cultivated as an ornamental plant for its vibrant foliage and ease of care.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha schinzii is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, including countries such as Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Madagascar. It is commonly found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and shrublands. This plant thrives in areas with high humidity and well-drained soil. It is often seen growing along stream banks and in swampy areas. Acalypha schinzii is also occasionally found in parts of southern Asia, though its primary range remains in Africa.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha schinzii was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage. The plant has since become naturalized in certain regions, particularly in the North Island. It is often found growing in disturbed soils and along roadsides. However, it is not considered a major invasive species in New Zealand.
